At least Cypriot policy iz more direct and visible and hit the uber wealthy with everyone else, but rest assured both policiez accomplish the same endz - taxing bank savingz.

Topic.Title: Fed policy iz more insidous then Cyproit proposalz

Message.Msg: The policy cripples the elderly (zero interest for people who depend on savings income) and the poor (creates inflation in food and energy leaving zero $ for anything else) while making the rich even richer (throughcreating equity and Bond bubble simultaneously). You can easily argue this price-fixing by the FED (condoned by the Administration) is the biggest contributor to wealth disparity in the US, not free-market capitalism! It's amazing - set up a plan/policy to suck money from the poor/middle class to give it to the rich, and then raise taxes on rich and distribute it back to the poor/middle class as gvt determines creating incentives for the low/middle class to live as gvt desires. All the while centralizing power and destroying freedom. It ain't going to end well.
Maybe Bezos can use his recovered Apollo parts in one of Amazon's great analogies. Our sales growth and non profits fell like the Apollo space crafts falling out of the sky into the ocean.

Message.Title: Genius
Message.Msg: Steve Jobs Jeff Bezos Bill Gates (in that order)

Topic.Title: Fed policy iz more insidous then Cyproit proposalz

Message.Msg: The most humorous thing was Bernanke saying the Fed is not targeting asset prices. Nothing could be further from the truth. Having said that, it is discovering that the second order effects of its actions are as big or bigger than the first order effects, making further increases in asset prices increasingly difficult. Many (like this pig) have nowhere to go but down. The only chance to keep ramping S&P is to use funny money here and elsewhere to rotate to real companies/invesments in which people have some degree of confidence on the fundamentals....

Topic.Title: Fed policy iz more insidous then Cyproit proposalz

Message.Msg: And I still think it fails... Only truly viable solution involves a Steve Keen style debt jubilee / QE for the people. But, that has huge moral hazard issues (although it's not like QE for the banks, which is the existing plan, doesn't...). The only way out of this mess is significant domestic real productivity growth from actual investment in innovation and productive physical assets (geared toward lower minimum efficient scale of production). All the pong in the world cannot solve the problem... As long as printed money continues to be used for speculative "investing" in non-productive financial assets, we are just going to lose ground...

Message.Title: Longs are you Sad?
Message.Msg: Geeg - are u sweating?
just bought some puts, so I can start sweating

I guess we'll be sweating all the way down to 120. There is a crucial difference between discretionary FCF and encumbered cash due to working capital management (especially when those that have enabled it are fighting back and competitors are seeking to capitalize). Current ratio about 1 even after raising $3B in LT debt... Plenty of off balance sheet obligations. Simply stated, a great risk free play... Or, as some have said about 30 YR treasuries, return free risk... The difference is only the Fed is buying 30YRs while everyone else is shortening duration. Here, you have "investors" buying return free with even greater risk...
guess it will or should I say did Now will it close below 255?

Geegee, When you say shorts are sad you imply that most shorts here are anti American or anti-markets. I think to the contrary. Most are proud Americans and love our capitalistic system. I think what they are against is the miss use of Fed money and how the 1% manipulate the system to extract wealth from the 99% ( footnote: Sybilrulz) And they are anti-bubble. Wishing for markets that operate without outside intervention. And I think that most view AMZN as the postboy for all that ills the system. I commend them for having the smarts to not follow like the rest of the sheep. Even tho most (me included) have taken a beatin' the last 4 months. - PJ
it will get really painful when the panic starts

PJ: On target here. I want people to make money and lots of it. But, by actually creating value and capturing a fraction of it. Not from glorified theft. At some point, there's not much more to take and it leads to bad outcomes. Capital markets need to reward actual value creation and value capture, not function as a skimming operation. That creates no value. It simply transfers from one party to another. M&A isn't returning as expected because sophisticated investors know most of this is overvalued #$%$. One way or another, the system will come back into balance. It can either happen by "investors" becoming investors again, or through a black swan...

Nope... Thanks for asking, dummy... Now sybs got a few questionz for geegee: How are those callz you said you loaded up on yesterday doing? What did you pay for each contract? When do they expire? What iz the strike price?

The system is efficient because of its nature. Shorts add value by adding some resistance and derivitive contracts like puts and calls allows management of risk. Futures market the same. it may not be perfect but it works preety well. here is Warren Buffet's take The U.S. economy “is coming back because of the natural juices of capitalism and not because of government,” Buffett told Business Wire’s Cathy Baron Tamraz in a video interview posted online today. “We have a wonderful system that eventually is self-cleansing and always moves forward.”

All the while centralizing power and destroying freedom. It ain't going to end well" Exaaaactly.... We have a winner in the catagory of True Understanding. You could also add the systemic degradation of "entitlements" to the arguement. "Entitlements". Sybil lovez that word.... Yep all the unemployement insurance, the SS, and the medicare premiumz that sybil haz paid for for YEARZ and not collected on any are now classified by the uber rich az handout "entitlements" that will be fully erroded before sybs gets to collect on any of them.

2011 $15.3T GDP. 2012 $15.7T GDP. Gov't deficit over $1.2T. Spending counts toward GDP. Debt does not count against GDP as it is simply a current activity indicator, not a "net wealth" indicator. The Fed is simply trying to prevent nominal asset prices from falling. If a business had those financials, we wouldn't say it is "coming back"...

Message.Msg: I know it!
instead of starting another armchair discussion, you'd better liquidate the puts you bought earlier this morning now. Then you can start one.
You are leaving the biggest and most important one. The one that will unseat amazon. EBAY

Actually, the one that will whoop Amazon is Google. Google will make massive investments to bring real time inventory information from the giants (WMT, TGT, etc) and focused big box category leaders (Best Buy, #$%$/Sports Authority, Border's, etc, etc) into its shopping platform where consumers can then optimize based upon total delivered cost and convenience. Throw in a growing network of local delivery/courier as a service and Amazon's value proposition is much diminished... eBay will eat away at the 3P side of things as well. Between both of them, Amazon's decision to ramp up fixed cost will prove mistaken...
